abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Livestock Sector Development Project
            for Cameroon. The major objectives of this project were to:
            (i) increase meat and milk production, (ii) improve
            producer's incomes; and (iii) reduce the financial
            burden on the Government services provided to the livestock
            sub-sector. To reach these objectives, both policy reforms
            and investments were used. The project did not achieve most
            of its objectives, which were too many and too ambitious and
            the project design was too complex, covering the whole
            country. Although, during preparation, appraisal and the
            first year of implementation, the Government was committed
            to the project, this attitude changed with time and its
            support became less evident, in part because of the repeated
            suspensions of disbursements (country related), and the
            resulting spacing of project supervisions. Apart from the
            difficult macro-economic circumstances that affected the
            whole country, the original project size and its complexity
            hindered its sustainability. Overall, Bank performance was
            mixed. Project objectives were consistent with Government
            priorities and Bank strategy for Cameroon. The project
            outcome is unsatisfactory because, it is not expected to
            have any substantial development impact. Lessons learned
            included: 1) Any operation related to the field of livestock
            development in Cameroon should limit the involvement of the
            public sector to a minimum; 2) The mid-term review should
            have been organized earlier and not 4 years after the
            project inception; and 3) The successful performance of the
            Tsetse control component and the role played by the MSEG
            demonstrated again the importance of: (a) decentralization;
            (b) the one-line-command approach; and (c) the highest
            possible degree of autonomy.
